rev.diff:
Line 44: Line 44:
==Background==
==Background==
â
Seif grew up in a family of activists, and activism was a constant topic of discussion in Mona's childhood. Her father, [[Ahmad Seif]], is a human rights attorney who was imprisoned five years. During his detention, he was tortured. Her mother, [[Laila Soueif]], is also an activist and a mathematics professor. She helped organize demonstrations against the Mubarak regime over the decades before his downfall. She was with a group of women assaulted by Mubarak thugs in 2005 where Mona's older brother, [[Alaa Abd El-Fatah|Alaa]], protected his mother breaking his arm. Her mother is known as, "brash and courageous, and has on numerous occasions faced down baton-wielding policemen with nothing but her scolding, scathing, booming voice and steely eyes".<ref name=cnn/> Mona's brother Alaa is a programmer and popular internet activist. He and his wife, Manal, created the Egyptian blog aggregator ''Manalaa''. From 2005 onward Alaa documented increasing abuses by the Mubarak regime. Alaa, was arrested at a demonstration in 2006 and imprisoned for 45 days. Mona and Manal helped organize a worldwide online campaign to free him. Mona's younger sister, Sanaa, is also involved in organizing protests.<ref name=cnn>{{cite web|author=By Scott Bronstein, CNN Special Investigations Unit |url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/meast/06/16/arab.unrest.irevolution/ |title=For Egyptian online warrior, father's torture fueled activism |publisher=CNN.com |date= |accessdate=2011-06-17}}</ref>
+
Seif grew up in a family of activists, and activism was a constant topic of discussion in Mona's childhood. Her father, [[Ahmad Seif]], is a human rights attorney who was imprisoned five years. During his detention, he was tortured. Her mother, [[Laila Soueif]], is also an activist and a mathematics professor. She helped organize demonstrations against the Mubarak regime over the decades before his downfall. She was with a group of women assaulted by Mubarak thugs in 2005 where Mona's older brother, [[Alaa Abd El-Fatah|Alaa]], protected his mother breaking his arm. Her mother is known as, "brash and courageous, and has on numerous occasions faced down baton-wielding policemen with nothing but her scolding, scathing, booming voice and steely eyes".<ref name=cnn/> Mona's brother Alaa is a programmer and popular internet activist. He and his wife, Manal, created the Egyptian blog aggregator ''Manalaa''. From 2005 onward Alaa documented increasing abuses by the Mubarak regime. Alaa, was arrested at a demonstration in 2006 and imprisoned for 45 days. Mona and Manal helped organize a worldwide online campaign to free him. Mona's younger sister, Sanaa, is also involved in organizing protests.<ref name=cnn>{{cite news|author=By Scott Bronstein, CNN Special Investigations Unit |url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/meast/06/16/arab.unrest.irevolution/ |title=For Egyptian online warrior, father's torture fueled activism |publisher=CNN.com |date= |accessdate=2011-06-17}}</ref>
Seif is a cancer research lab worker, but much of her time is spent pursuing human and civil rights reforms.<ref name=cnn/>
Seif is a cancer research lab worker, but much of her time is spent pursuing human and civil rights reforms.<ref name=cnn/>
Line 55: Line 55:
==Post-Mubarak==
==Post-Mubarak==
[[File:Noor Ayman & Mona Seif.jpg|thumb|Nour ''([[Ayman Nour]]'s son)'' & Mona Seif.]]
[[File:Noor Ayman & Mona Seif.jpg|thumb|Nour ''([[Ayman Nour]]'s son)'' & Mona Seif.]]
â
Seif is a member of ''No to Military Trials of Civilians'', a group pushing for the release of those detained during the revolution, the movement of civilians from military courts to trials by a civil judge, and, investigation of torture allegations involving military police.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/467893 |title=Military promises activists it will review military trials of civilians | Al-Masry Al-Youm: Today's News from Egypt |publisher=Al-Masry Al-Youm |date=2011-06-01 |accessdate=2011-06-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/14285/Egypt/Politics-/Egypt%E2%80%99s-ruling-military-makes-promises-to-No-to-Mi.aspx |title=Egyptâs ruling military makes promises to No to Military Trials campaigners - Politics - Egypt - Ahram Online |publisher=English.ahram.org.eg |date= |accessdate=2011-06-17}}</ref><ref>http://thedailynewsegypt.com/human-a-civil-rights/scaf-promises-to-reconsider-military-trials.html</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.npr.org/2011/06/14/137176946/egypts-secret-military-trials-erode-activists-trust |title=Egypt's Secret Military Trials Erode Activists' Trust |publisher=NPR |date= |accessdate=2011-06-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Hennessy |first=Molly |url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fg-egypt-prisoners-20110527,0,5482207.story |title=Egypt democracy protests: Egyptian activists plan protests over military trials |publisher=latimes.com |date=2011-05-27 |accessdate=2011-06-17}}</ref> Seif wrote on her blog ''Ma3t'', about the military police during crackdowns on Tahrir protesters, requesting people come forward with their stories.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thedailynewsegypt.com/human-a-civil-rights/bloggers-slam-army-council-in-anti-scaf-blogging-day.html |title=Bloggers slam army council in anti-SCAF blogging day |publisher=Thedailynewsegypt.com |date= |accessdate=2011-06-17}}</ref>
+
Seif is a member of ''No to Military Trials of Civilians'', a group pushing for the release of those detained during the revolution, the movement of civilians from military courts to trials by a civil judge, and, investigation of torture allegations involving military police.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/467893 |title=Military promises activists it will review military trials of civilians | Al-Masry Al-Youm: Today's News from Egypt |publisher=Al-Masry Al-Youm |date=2011-06-01 |accessdate=2011-06-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/14285/Egypt/Politics-/Egypt%E2%80%99s-ruling-military-makes-promises-to-No-to-Mi.aspx |title=Egyptâs ruling military makes promises to No to Military Trials campaigners - Politics - Egypt - Ahram Online |publisher=English.ahram.org.eg |date= |accessdate=2011-06-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://thedailynewsegypt.com/human-a-civil-rights/scaf-promises-to-reconsider-military-trials.html |title=SCAF promises to reconsider military trials |publisher=Thedailynewsegypt.com |date= |accessdate=2011-06-22}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.npr.org/2011/06/14/137176946/egypts-secret-military-trials-erode-activists-trust |title=Egypt's Secret Military Trials Erode Activists' Trust |publisher=NPR |date= |accessdate=2011-06-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Hennessy |first=Molly |url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fg-egypt-prisoners-20110527,0,5482207.story |title=Egypt democracy protests: Egyptian activists plan protests over military trials |publisher=latimes.com |date=2011-05-27 |accessdate=2011-06-17}}</ref> Seif wrote on her blog ''Ma3t'', about the military police during crackdowns on Tahrir protesters, requesting people come forward with their stories.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thedailynewsegypt.com/human-a-civil-rights/bloggers-slam-army-council-in-anti-scaf-blogging-day.html |title=Bloggers slam army council in anti-SCAF blogging day |publisher=Thedailynewsegypt.com |date= |accessdate=2011-06-17}}</ref>
She has been critcal of the action's of Egypt's interm ruling body the [[Supreme Council of the Armed Forces]] (SCAF) saying, of the release of protesters without full exoneration: âThe fact that they have suspended sentences does not give them the pride they deserve as revolutionaries who did nothing wrong."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/~/NewsContent/1/64/12804/Egypt/Politics-/Majority-of-activists-in-military-prisons-released.aspx |title=Majority of activists in military prisons released, criticism of SCAF continues - Politics - Egypt - Ahram Online |publisher=English.ahram.org.eg |date=2011-05-24 |accessdate=2011-06-17}}</ref>
She has been critcal of the action's of Egypt's interm ruling body the [[Supreme Council of the Armed Forces]] (SCAF) saying, of the release of protesters without full exoneration: âThe fact that they have suspended sentences does not give them the pride they deserve as revolutionaries who did nothing wrong."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/~/NewsContent/1/64/12804/Egypt/Politics-/Majority-of-activists-in-military-prisons-released.aspx |title=Majority of activists in military prisons released, criticism of SCAF continues - Politics - Egypt - Ahram Online |publisher=English.ahram.org.eg |date=2011-05-24 |accessdate=2011-06-17}}</ref>
